posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: I found a method to obtain input from a TI 84 Plus CE calculator and feed it into the driver station. I reviewed the rulebook and did not find any restrictions on using the calculator as a controller. Here's how it functions: A C program on the calculator sends key inputs as keyboard strokes via a USB connection. Another program on the operator console translates keypresses into gamepad inputs that the Driver Station can process. I’m unsure if this is allowed during a match, but I didn’t discover any prohibitions.

link_counts.title: GitHub - Powerbyte7/HIDeous: Turns the Ti-84 CE into a working keyboard
GitHub - luttje/Key2Joy: Simulate a GameController/Joystick using your keyboard and mouse.

posts.cooked: Does anyone know if this is prohibited during a match? I don’t really know too well what you can and can’t do, and as stated previously, haven’t found anything prohibiting it. You can use effectively anything you want as a driver station if it only communicates through FMS and uses nothing wireless and doesn’t do anything prohibited like confusing robots with weird vision targets.

posts.name: Justin Nesselrotte
posts.cooked:
A memorable moment was the TI-84+ SE; its USB features were all handled in z80 assembly.  
The section relevant to you is 8.9 in the manual; the CE model adheres to those standards. Thus, it's fully functional and compatible.

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked: how soon until i can plot a path on the calc and then the robot follows it

When the Driver Station window is in focus, it causes all keyboard inputs to be blocked, making Key2Joy ineffective. This issue likely affects any software designed to convert keyboard inputs to controller signals. If you're working within a tabbed interface, such as a dashboard window or another application, the function should operate normally, though using additional hardware like an Arduino can help prevent such problems. Notably, this concern applies even when using a TI 84 Plus CE calculator as a robot controller, so it's worth noting in case you ever encounter it.

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: I modified a program from https://github.com/Powerbyte7/HIDeous that controls the calculator’s USB port to send HID keyboard reports, creating a custom descriptor for a gamepad layout. This setup allows one axis to function correctly along with all buttons. I am currently working on enabling a second axis to achieve Xbox controller compatibility, eliminating the need for additional robot program changes. Once complete, I will share my code on GitHub, offering flexibility to map any calculator button to any gamepad axis or preset configuration.

accepted_answer.excerpt:
Ah I remember back in the day with the TI-84+ SE, but all of our USB related stuff was z80 assembly! 
The section you care about is 8.9 in the game manual, and the TI-84+ CE doesn’t violate any of those rules. So you should be good to go. It’s equivalent to bringing your own USB based control with a…
